key_channel_insights.line_content: OTAs priced below the website on 38% of itineraries, peaking at 75% for NL-origin routes and signaling persistent short-haul margin pressure.
MSEs undercut site fares on 77% of listings, yet the average discount is a mere 0.06%, creating revenue leakage without a meaningful customer price advantage.
GDS shows higher fares 67% of the time (0.11% premium) while 61% of long-haul itineraries are simply missing, limiting visibility in corporate channels.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: Last week OTAs priced below the website on 37.6% of O-Ds, versus 22.1% higher and 26.5% in parity.
For NL origins, OTAs were cheaper on 74.6% of routes and almost never higher (0.7%).
On long-haul, OTAs were higher on 19.9% of pairs and never cheaper, concentrating risk on short-haul.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: OTA absence fell 0.8 ppt WoW but still affects one in seven itineraries—an opportunity to close content gaps.
Parity rate is stable at 26.5% (-0.5 ppt WoW) suggesting limited progress toward uniform pricing.
Incidence edged up 0.4 ppt; average discount remains modest at 4%, yet signals persistent undercutting.
When higher, OTAs carry a 19% premium, indicating scope to raise website fares on selective O-Ds.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: OTAs cheaper on 46.8% of routes (avg ‑4%) versus 22.7% higher (+21%); content gaps minimal at 2.3%.
No cases of OTA cheaper; 19.9% show OTA premium (+5%) but 60.8% offers missing—coverage is the main issue.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Three-quarters of NL itineraries favor OTAs (-3% discount), reflecting aggressive partner promotion.
Outside NL, OTAs charge more on 43.5% (+19%) while undercutting just 0.8%; the website is price-competitive abroad.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: OTAs cheaper on 36.4% (-3%); higher on 22.3% (+17%); parity at 26.4%.
39.8% OTA cheaper (-4%) vs 21.7% higher (+22%); undercutting persists across the curve.

mse_highlights.line_content: 77% of website fares are undercut on MSE, but the average discount is only 0.06%.
Price-match instances rose to 10.3% of listings, while ‘MSE Lower’ share fell 1.6 ppts WoW.
60% of long-haul itineraries are not shown on MSE, risking diversion of high-yield traffic.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Still high but down 0.9 ppt WoW; gap concentrated in long-haul markets.
Now 10.3% (+2.4 ppts WoW), reflecting improving price discipline.
At 77.1%, yet slipping 1.6 ppts; discount remains negligible (-0.06%).

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: 91% cheaper on MSE (-0.06%); parity at 8% and improving—room to lift website rates.
60% of offers missing; only 21% cheaper and 18% match the site.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 85% price lower on MSE with virtually no premiums; parity at 3%.
Lower-priced share drops to 69% while parity climbs to 18%, signaling healthier alignment abroad.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 78% price lower, same 0.06% discount; visibility slightly better (11.8% not found).

gds_highlights.line_content: GDS showed higher fares 67% of the time; lower fares almost nonexistent (0.06%).
Where higher, the average premium is just 0.11%, posing limited revenue risk.
61% of long-haul itineraries were not available in GDS, limiting corporate reach.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Website offers missing in GDS for one in eight O-Ds; gap narrowed 1.2 ppts MoM.
Parity up 1.2 ppts WoW but still below one-quarter of supply.
Higher fares on 67.2%; frequency flat WoW, +1.8 ppts MoM.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: GDS higher on 78.8% with a 0.12% premium; availability near total (0.4% not found).
60.6% not found; only 20.1% higher-priced hits—distribution, not pricing, is the core issue.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Higher fares 54.3% of the time; premium modest at 0.05%; parity solid at 33.4%.
GDS higher on 80% with 0.16% markup; parity drops to 7.6%.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 60.4% GDS premiums (0.12% gap); parity improved ~2 ppts WoW.
80.3% GDS higher despite small 0.10% premium; offer absence widening.
